Entries.default: "The Children of the Dawnstars. I wondered if we'd run into them down here."

"Hey, there's a lady I'm looking for, came from Dyrwood."

Edér waves a hand in the old woman's face, as though expecting cataracts she does not appear to have.
"You know how I've been saying there's nothing more important to me than us freeing you from Berath's bonds?"
Edér's head hangs at a slight tilt. His eyes search restlessly.
"Had a hunch they might be idiots. Just didn't know how big."
Edér deflates. "We missed it."
"There's someone I used to know... just an old friend. Came out here to settle with them, last I heard."
"Maybe we should ask around, see if she's still out here. Might be she can help us."
"How did you know her?"

"Uh, well... Both grew up in Gilded Vale... Same temple..."

Edér looks askance at you.
"Your cheeks are red."
"If you say so."
"You can trust me, you know."
"All right, all right, we used to uh... you know..."
"I get the picture."
"That's my favorite kind!"
"I knew you'd understand. You're gonna like her, I got a good feeling."
"Short, got a bad temper. Goes by Elafa Maesy. Heard of her?"
"I know an Elafa but that ain't her surname."
"Not real warm, that one - stop by unannounced, you get a pistol up your nose when she answers the door."

"No?"

Edér's jaw shifts sideways to gnaw on his pipe stem.
"Yeah, that's, uh, that's her. So she's living with her uh, husband, then?"

"Not that I noticed."

Edér exhales a surprising amount of air.
"Huh, must be laying low."
"...just that boy of hers."
"She tries that with me, she'll get one in each nostril."
Edér's body goes perfectly still. It seems to waver in the breeze.
"Something the matter?"
"She's got a son? Uh, how old would you say? Like a little boy?"
"Oh, this is getting good."

"Nah, just curious."

Edér's grip on his pipe has caused the color to drain from his knuckles.
"Oh, I couldn't say. It's been years. He must be a young man by now."
"Wow, that's, uh, that's something. Well, thanks for your help."
"Don't you want to know where to find her?"
"Yeah, I was... just about to ask."
"She's in Hasongo, last I heard. Got a little plot of land out there."
"Guess we'll look that way, then. Much obliged."

"Well I meant that. I did."

Edér's breath lingers in his chest and his mouth hangs ajar, throwing his statement into immediate doubt.
"But there's this other thing I need to see about. On the way, like. I was gonna tell you."
"It's about love. You don't have to explain."
"In a journey full of obstacles, what's one more?"
"Why not? I use you for my ends all the time."
"It's only fair."
"Thanks, I'm not sure I could anyway."

"I don't see it like an obstacle. Not unless she's mad.

"She might be mad."

"Exactly, you understand. You uh... wait, how's that?"

He shakes it off and continues.
"Glad you see it that way. This thing with the gods holding your soul for ransom, we're still gonna take care of that. Right after."

"This woman. I, uh... well love's not the right word. But she was something to me once, back in Gilded Vale."

He pauses.
"When I was mayor of Dyrford, I had this vision of what I wanted it to look like. It was gonna be what Gilded Vale was, before the Legacy."
"After the Legacy ended, all I could think about was how to repair what the gods had done."
"Once Thaos was gone, there wasn't much keeping me in Dyrwood. Thought I'd be happier in Aedyr where my folks had gone."
"Anyway, I don't expect you to understand. But I gotta know she ended up all right."
"It sounds like she ended up with a son."
"This can't wait until after Berath has released me?"
"Nothing personal but I don't know that there will be an after. Even though you may be the only one I wouldn't bet against."
"I followed you once when there was something you had to do to put your soul at ease. We went through a lot but we did it."
"Now I'm asking you to let me see to mine."
"Yeah that's- that's something. Coming out of Dyrwood during that time."
"When I knew her, she had another little boy, just a baby. But the Legacy deprived him of a proper life."
"I never found out what happened to him, but with the Hollowborn, you didn't have to ask."

"Guess he got a brother, though."

Edér falls quiet, blinking several times before noting your continued presence.
"You're sure you want to know where this leads?"
"No. But I don't see a way to let this go. Leastaways not now."
"Last time I saw Elafa, we got friendly. Now she's got a son."
Edér's shrug is rigid, his smile at least half wince.

"In my head I thought we'd get here and she'd scold me for not leaving her alone."

"That would've been enough for me."
"She was someone who could survive anything. She should be here."
"At least you know what became of her."
"You must feel awful. I feel awful."
"Maybe she's just hiding from you? "
"Well, this has been a total waste."

"Doesn't seem real."

He shakes his head.
"Hey, if you need a shoulder to cry on, I'm right here."
"I guess so."
"Guess it's possible. That last night, it wasn't my best performance."
"That boy, he looks like her. But it's hard to believe she raised him."
"Look in his eyes had more in common with his big brother than with his mom."
"Never heard of these Partisans of the Lighted Path, but I know the type."
"If they fancy themselves soldiers, we can give them a fight."
"Perhaps we should meet them and see for ourselves."
"They sound like they just have strong convictions. I can respect that."
"I bet they're fun at dinner feasts."
"Most days, I'm against persecuting Eothasians. Now I'm starting to see the other side of it."
"You might be right about that. Though I'd rather be doing just about anything else."
"Sure. Just like Thaos."
"You almost wish you could lock 'em in a room with Durance. See how fast they talk their way through the air supply."
"Elafa'd say leave it alone. She'd say I'd only make a mess of things."
"But that boy's all that's left of her now. If there's anything left at all."
"Be the Effigy if I don't pay these Partisans of the Lighted Path a visit."
"Bearn, he's gonna be getting on that ship, from what it sounded like."
"They're gonna park that thing next to Eothas and slit their own throats."
"Wish they'd gone ahead with it before they got Bearn involved."
"If we can't catch it..."
"Yes, we'll go right now."
"We'll get there when I'm able."
"He's a goner. No point in chasing."
"Maybe not for you, but there is for me. You in, or am I going alone?"
"We'll go after him."
"You're on your own."
"That so? Guess that's it, then."
"All right, well. Good luck with the big statue and your soul."
"I knew there was something I liked about you."
"All right, just- let's not be late."
"Hey that's- we met a young fella out there, kinda reminded me of Elafa. He said he didn't know her."
"Why would he lie?"
"You're eager to see her, but you're trying to hide it. Why?"
"Heh, and she was real loud, too. Used to have to cover her mouth or she'd get the dog howling in the next room."
"Sounds like a special woman."
"You could've stopped a few sentences ago."
"I imagine settlers have to keep their guard up out here."
"Sounds like she's expecting you, Edér."
"That's why it's always best to sneak in through the back."
"Interesting."
"Start talking."
"And in some ways, it got there. I was proud of that."
"But it didn't feel like I thought it would. Come to realize there was someone I needed to show it to."
"Last I saw her, she was going to New Heomar. Went looking for her there only to find that she'd left a long time ago."
"Elafa, she'd have been about the last person left in Dyrwood who'd have seen what I made and understood."
"To me that meant seeing about making Eothasians feel safe in their own homes. That's how I found the Night Market."
"After a while of that I got to thinking about the days just after the war, when we all stopped feeling safe in the first place."
"Mostly I thought of the woman I couldn't help, who had to leave her home in the dead of night carrying a little baby that had no soul."
"It was nice seeing them again. Been almost since the war."
"But I didn't belong. Found I couldn't talk to anyone, and not just because of the funny way Aedyrans talk."
"We merely swallow our food first."
"Over there, across the ocean, it's like nothing I'd been through ever happened. Not the war, not the Legacy."
"Even my parents missed most of it. And I'm glad about that. But all we had to talk about was stuff from when I was a boy."
"Then I thought of somebody I knew I could talk to. Maybe the last person. And just like that I was back on a boat, going the other way."
"I mentioned the baby she had when I knew her. That was a boy, too."
"Let's get moving."
Edér cracks a grudging smile.
[Nod.]
Edér is quiet a moment.
Edér snorts.
"Doubt they ever get past the pre-dinner prayer rituals."
"Can you promise me we'll go right now?"
"You had no right to do that. That boy wasn't hurting anyone."
"I'll be going my own way from now on. This is over."
[Stare at Edér.]
"Just a friend, huh?" Xoti rubs the back of her neck, clearly uncomfortable.
Xoti's face mottles bright red, and she turns away, hands covering her eyes.
"Is this a provincial euphemism, or were you actually being discreet?"
"Not sure whether the mental image I just got were from you or from me. Well done either way."
Groaning, Xoti pulls her hair forward over her face as if she can hide from the moment.

Aloth's eyes go wide with shock.

Then delight.

He's watching Edér the way a cat watches a wounded mouse.
Pallegina's golden eyes grow wide as she looks back and forth between the pair.
"This is larger than your personal concerns, Edér. If we don't reach Eothas, none of this will matter."
"I don't blame you for going. But, well, I wish you wouldn't."
"Corès, aimico."
"Now we've got to find someone else to lug around our heavy shields."
"But then who'll be standing betwixt me and the pointy bits of things?"
"I got my limits Aloth. Maybe you should ask yourself about yours."

"Sorry I won't be staying on to the end. I wanted to see this through."

Edér walks off. He does not look back.

"Edér, this is your chance to speak to Eothas! Our chance to set things right.

"Please, let's do this. Together."
"Wait. Where will you go? We... we might never see each other again."

"Do something for me, Aloth. If he's doing right, help him out. 

"If he's not... tell him I'll be holding him to account, one way or another."

"Xoti, you, uh... you surprised me. If Gaun doesn't see what I see in you, you tell him he's not good enough for you.

"That goes for anyone, man or god."

He seems about to step toward her, but stays rooted in place as though indecision were thick mud around his boots. He manages only an awkward nod and halfhearted smile.
"Look, I know you got a lot going on. But we gotta hurry if we're gonna get to Bearn in time."
"I'd be happy to help you with the math."
"Fye, ye've just to squawk a mite louder tae drown 'em out!"
